generif.text: Data suggest that separase is required for sister chromatid separation during mitosis in human cells, and that securin inhibits separase by blocking the access of substrates to the active site of separase.
Anaphase specific auto-cleavage of separase.
Processing, localization, and requirement of separase for normal anaphase progression.

Separase function is not restricted to anaphase initiation; its role in promoting loss of sister chromatid cohesion might be preferentially at arms but not centromeres.
nuclear exclusion is important to prevent cohesin cleavage during interphase in the absence of securin and the phosphorylation inhibition
Protein phosphatase 2A and separase form a complex regulated by separase autocleavage
Phosphorylation promotes complex formation indirectly, possibly by inducing a conformational change in full-length separase.
The complete removal of cohesin from chromosome arms depends on separase.

Study reports that cohesin cleavage by human separase requires DNA in a sequence-nonspecific manner.

Separase might be an oncogene, whose overexpression induces tumorigenesis. Separase overexpression and aberrant nuclear localization are common in many tumor types and may predict outcome in some human cancers.

Plk1-mediated phosphorylation of Cdc6 promotes the interaction of Cdc6 and Cdk1, leading to the attenuation of Cdk1 activity, release of separase, and subsequent anaphase progression.
SMC3 and separase are upregulated and securin is downregulated in malignant transformation of BEAS-2B cells induced by coal tar pitch smoke extracts.
Results identify a new functional role of securin and separase in the modulation of membrane traffic and protein secretion that implicates regulation of V-ATPase assembly and function.

Kendrin is a novel and crucial substrate for separase (ESPL1) at the centrosome, protecting the engaged centrioles from premature disengagement and thereby blocking reduplication until the cell passes through mitosis.
By consecutively acting as a protease and a cdk1 inhibitor, separase coordinates two key processes to achieve simultaneous and abrupt separation of sister chromatids.
Mutation of the homologous position in PTTG1 (H(134)) switched PTTG1 from an inhibitor into an activator of ESP1.

Separase is an oncogene whose overexpression induces tumorigenesis, and indicate that Separase overexpression and aberrant nuclear localization are common in many tumor types and may predict outcome in some human malignancies.
High ESPL1 mRNA expression was associated with luminal B breast cancers.
Recruitment and activation of separase at centrosomes are two distinct steps that do not require microtubules.
Data indicate that separase is subject to native-state cis/trans isomerization by peptidyl-prolyl-isomerase Pin1.

The assay was used to quantify Separase proteolytic activity in leukemic cell lines and peripheral blood samples from leukemia patients.
Proximity mapping of human separase has been presented.

Studies identified and characterized the role of separase in mitosis, meiosis, non-canonical roles, its regulation, as a regulator of centriole disengagement, non proteolytic roles, diverse substrates, structural insights, and association of separase with cancer. [review]
High ESP expression is associated with breast cancer.

Thus, tethering of separase to DSBs and confined cohesin cleavage promote DSB repair in G2 cells. Importantly, this conserved interphase function of separase protects mammalian cells from oncogenic transformation.
LPE motif on the Scc1 substrate is required for rapid and specific cleavage by separase.

data suggests an association between high separase activity, residual BCR-ABL1 gene expression, and enhanced proliferative capacity in hematopoietic cells within the leukemic niche of TKI-treated chronic phase CML.

human cells that enter mitosis with already active separase rapidly undergo death in mitosis owing to direct cleavage of anti-apoptotic MCL1 and BCL-XL by separase; separase-triggered apoptosis enforces minimal length of mitosis

BP.term: positive regulation of mitotic metaphase/anaphase transition
negative regulation of sister chromatid cohesion

name: extra spindle pole bodies like 1, separase

kegg.name: Human T-cell leukemia virus 1 infection - Homo sapiens (human)

wikipathways.name: Regulation of sister chromatid separation at the metaphase-anaphase transition

summary: Stable cohesion between sister chromatids before anaphase and their timely separation during anaphase are critical for chromosome inheritance. In vertebrates, sister chromatid cohesion is released in 2 steps via distinct mechanisms. The first step involves phosphorylation of STAG1 (MIM 604358) or STAG2 (MIM 300826) in the cohesin complex. The second step involves cleavage of the cohesin subunit SCC1 (RAD21; MIM 606462) by ESPL1, or separase, which initiates the final separation of sister chromatids (Sun et al., 2009 [PubMed 19345191]).[supplied by OMIM, Nov 2010].
